thread.section_title: Arts and Entertainment coverage for all ages and interests - San Francisco Chronicle
thread.title: Radio Waves: Lotsa luck at radio Hall of Fame inductions
thread.title_full: Radio Waves: Lotsa luck at radio Hall of Fame inductions - San Francisco Chronicle

author: Ben Fong-Torres
title: Radio Waves: Lotsa luck at radio Hall of Fame inductions
text:
Photo: Composite Photo ByKenny Wardell At the Radio Hall of Fame luncheon (l to r): Dusty Street, Mike Colgan, Lissa Kreisler, Harvey Stone, Gil Haar, and, representing Ken Neilsen and Peter Scott: Bill Ruck, Zia Schwartz. At the Radio Hall of Fame luncheon (l to r): Dusty Street, Mike...
Anybody remember Jack McDonald ? John Madden does. The legendary football coach and broadcaster, inducted into the Bay Area Radio Hall of Fame on Sept. 19, said in a video interview that, growing up in Daly City, his first play-by-play hero was McDonald, who called San Francisco Seals baseball games in the ’40s. His home run call, said Madden, was “It’s gone! It’s out Aunt Maggie’s window!” As a broadcaster himself, Madden was teamed with Gene Nelson on KSFO, then Frank Dill and Mike Cleary on KNBR, then Al Hart and, now, Stan Bunger on KCBS. “All Hall of Famers,” he noted. On TV, it’s mainly been Pat Summerall and Al Michaels . “That’s pretty good. I’m the luckiest guy in the world.” At the Radio Hall of Fame luncheon (l to r): Dusty Street, Mike Colgan, Lissa Kreisler, Harvey Stone, Gil Haar, and, representing Ken Neilsen and Peter Scott: Bill Ruck, Zia Schwartz. At the Radio Hall of Fame luncheon (l to r): Dusty Street, Mike...
